awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: LSC Center for Coatings Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) Center for Coatings Research (CCR), funded by the NSF and with planned co-funding by the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, seeks to extend the reach of the next generation of gravitational wave detectors by addressing the dominant noise source limiting their performance, thermal noise in the interferometer mirrors. This noise reduces the number of observable gravitational wave signals from astronomical sources. It arises from thermal excitation of the vibrational modes of the mirrors in the LIGO detector optics. The effect of these excitations is reduced as the mechanical quality factor (Q) of the mirrors is increased. Since the Q of the mirrors is limited by the reflective coatings deposited on their surfaces, lower noise requires development of better coatings. The CCR combines groups from 10 institutions in the US working on computational modeling of amorphous materials, deposition of coatings, and characterization of their atomic structure and macroscopic properties. These components are often performed by three diverse communities that work in relative isolation from each other. The strength of the CCR and its promise of accelerating discoveries arises from close integration of these three communities focused on a unified research goal. Coating thermal noise is also a limiting factor in the fields of precision timing, quantum information, low noise interferometry, and precision measurements like the search for deviations in the gravitational inverse-square law. Coatings improving on the state of the art in mechanical and optical properties developed under this program would be applicable to these communities as well. On broader impacts in education, the mixture of undergraduate institutions with elite graduate programs provides research opportunities at all education levels and establishes clear avenues of advancement for students who wish to pursue a career within the physical sciences. In addition, the CCR has a strong commitment to the advancement of women and underrepresented minorities; and will also continue its participants' activities in issues of education and public outreach through all major channels of public and social media.

The A+ LIGO detector, planned for 2021, will reduce quantum noise with squeezed light injection, leaving thermal noise dominant in the mid-band of the detector.  Reducing this noise source requires reducing the mechanical dissipation in the mirror coatings on the test masses. The goal of this project is to develop mirror coatings consistent with A+ LIGO's mechanical and optical requirements. Meeting this goal requires solution of a longstanding problem in the physics of amorphous materials: the nature and control of the low-energy excitations in amorphous oxides. On a longer time scale, developing mirror coatings for the cryogenic LIGO Voyager detector broadens the possibilities to include amorphous or crystalline semiconductors. The primary research focus is to find conditions under which amorphous metal-oxide coatings can be deposited as "ultrastable glasses", which have a low density of the structural motifs that form two-level systems, the source of elastic dissipation. A second research track seeks methods to stabilize coatings against crystallization during high temperature annealing, another method known to reduce room temperature elastic losses. For the longer term research towards LIGO Voyager applications, the group will investigate non-oxide coatings such as single-crystal semiconductors AlGaAs and AlGaP, which have shown low mechanical loss for small geometries but whose scale up to the size of LIGO optics is challenging; and also amorphous silicon and silicon nitride, which have attractive mechanical properties but whose optical properties must be improved.

por.por_cntn:
A century after Einstein predicted their existence, the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) and its European partner Virgo have given humanity a new sense to observe the universe: gravitational waves. Gravitational waves are ripples of warped spacetime that travel at the speed of light. Following the discovery of gravitational waves in September 2015, the sensitivity of the LIGO and Virgo detectors has increased and their observations of the universe with gravitational waves have deepened. These waves are giving us new insight into the most extreme events in the universe: collisions of black holes and neutron stars.

The LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) Center for Coatings Research (CCR), co-funded by the NSF and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, consists of groups from nine institutions in the United States. Their close, integrated work seeks to understand and reduce the most important source of noise in the LIGO and Virgo detectors: thermal noise in the reflective coatings of the detectors’ mirrors. Coating thermal noise is random fluctuations in the coating’s position caused by its temperature. These fluctuations turn out to limit how sensitive LIGO and Virgo are to gravitational waves at the frequencies where the detectors are most sensitive. Reducing these fluctuations will increase the sensitivity of future gravitational-wave observatories, allowing them to observe gravitational waves from events that are farther from Earth.

One approach to reduce thermal noise is to explore whether different coating materials might have lower thermal noise while still being otherwise suitable for use in gravitational-wave detectors (for example, they must not scatter too much of the light that falls onto them in unwanted directions). The group at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF), has pursued two main approaches in that direction.

First, we developed an open-source code (https://github.com/geoffrey4444/NumericalCoatingThermalNoise) for modeling thermal noise in mirrors, including their thin, reflective coatings; our code is based on the deal-ii framework (https://dealii.org). It calculates thermal noise in mirror coatings made of different materials, including crystalline coatings, a promising but not yet fully understood alternative to conventional coatings. We used the code to assess how important crystalline effects are when computing coating thermal noise, finding that there is a small but noticeable difference when crystalline effects are neglected. We also used it to explore the importance of differences in the materials’ bulk and shear loss angles (which characterize how much energy is dissipated when a material is compressed or sheared) in models of the Brownian thermal noise. Finally, we shared our results with collaborators, discussing and reviewing their work to enable the SpECTRE code (https://spectre-code.org) to calculate thermal noise using a Discontinuous Galerkin method, which has potential to be much more accurate than in our conventional, finite-element code. SpECTRE’s goal is modeling gravitational-wave sources using numerical relativity; thermal noise calculations also serve as a step toward solving similar, but much more complex, equations for initial data for a simulation of two colliding black holes.

Second, we characterized the optical scattering of coatings that are promising candidates for improving the thermal noise of gravitational-wave detector optics. 

i) The current LIGO and Virgo optics have coatings formed from stacks of alternating high- and low-index of refraction amorphous materials. The high index material, titania-doped tantala, currently limits the thermal noise. Much effort has gone into doping, deposition methods, and annealing these coatings in order to minimize their thermal noise (and optical absorption). However, less is known about how these processes affect the material’s scattering. We imaged and measured scatter versus angle for more than a dozen samples with tantala-based coatings. Further, we developed a scatterometer capable of measuring scatter as the coatings are annealed in vacuum. We found that scatter depends on the coating procedure and usually decreases during vacuum annealing to temperatures lower than the material’s crystallization point. 

ii) A promising future coating material is crystalline AlGaAs, which can also be paired with GaAs to form coating stacks. We characterized two AlGaAs samples. We found that the scatter from these samples is quite low, 2-3ppm (below previously reported values), for most laser beam alignments, but can be higher, 10ppm, when the beam encounters a larger defect. Starting with one defect, work was done to match the scatter versus angle function with theory for scattering from circular defects, obtaining an estimate of 12 microns diameter. These techniques will be applied to further evaluate AlGaAs as a coating material. 

This project involved undergraduate and masters students from CSUF, a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution, in gravitational-wave research and outreach. Most of the student participants were from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in physics.These students contributed to coating technology for a discovery-making field while building transferable laboratory and computing skills. These experiences have helped the participants’ careers advance and several have secured positions in the STEM workforce.
